TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 2 December 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Were the Chinese nationals who arrived on Christmas Island advised of their rights to seek independent legal advice and to contact the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR); if so, did the Chinese freely waive these rights; if not, given that the boat concerned came via the same route and from the same place as a previous boat from which people have been granted refugee status, does this action constitute a breach of internationally agreed practice in relation to the treatment of (potential) asylum seekers.

(2) Were the Chinese nationals offered independent interpreters; if so, did the Chinese freely waive these rights; if not, given that the boat concerned came via the same route and from the same place as a previous boat from which people have been granted refugee status, does this action constitute a breach of internationally agreed practice in relation to the treatment of (potential) asylum seekers.

(3) Was there an independent observer present during the interview; if not, why was no effort made to ensure independent monitoring of the process, given that had such monitoring taken place, there could be no question about the events.
(4) Has the UNHCR been granted access to the information they requested about the event on Christmas Island.

(5) What happened to the 113 Chinese from Christmas Island and the seven repatriated involuntarily from Port Hedland when they returned to China; if this information is not known, why have there been no attempts made to monitor, either directly or indirectly, the fate of the returnees to see whether the assurances given by the Chinese Government were genuine.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The government fully accepts and implements the principle that persons seeking the protection of the Australian government must be given a proper opportunity to pursue their claim, and in particular to contact the UNHCR. The issues raised in the honourable senator's question are not, however, relevant to the group in question, who gave no indication that they were seeking the protection of the Australian government, and were not asylum seekers.

(2) The interpreters used to interview the Chinese nationals on Christmas Island were all accredited interpreters under temporary contract to my department for the duration of the exercise. This is normal procedure. To imply that they were not "independent" is to call into question their professionalism and their adherence to professional ethics. I am confident that any suggestions of this kind are completely unfounded.
(3) It is not usual for an observer to be present during interviews held with unauthorised arrivals at Australia's borders, nor was there one in this case.
(4) Yes.

(5) I have no specific information on what has happened to the 113 Chinese nationals since their return to China from Christmas Island. We have, as the honourable senator is aware, received repeated high level assurances that no returnee to China would be persecuted if his or her only action had been illegal departure from China. Information in my department's possession concerning the seven people removed from Port Hedland confirms the assurances given by Chinese authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 7 December 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to information given to Senator Baume at Estimates Committee hearings by officers of the Australian Heritage Commission that the Commission would notify the owners and developers of the National Estate values of the Cairns Customs House and would request that these be considered in any decision making process concerning redevelopment of the Customs House and the application which has been made to the Queensland Government, which will make a decision in relation to the successful developer of the casino and site:

(1) Has the Australian Heritage Commission made its attitude to the redevelopment of the Cairns Customs House known to the Queensland Government so that the Queensland Government is aware of these views before any decision is made; if not, why has the Commission not so advised the Queensland Government.

(2) Does the Commission believe that the Cairns Customs House is of significant heritage value; if so, what action apart from that notified in the answer to Senator Baume at the Estimates Committee hearing, is the Commission taking to promote its view in relation to the Cairns Customs House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Commission has contacted the Director of the Heritage Branch of the Queensland Department of Environment and Heritage concerning rumours of redevelopment at the Cairns Customs House. The Director of the Queensland Heritage Branch has noted the Commission's interest in the site and the Commission's view that national estate values should be considered in redevelopment proposals affecting a national estate place. The Queensland Heritage Branch has stated that redevelopment is only a concept and has undertaken to keep the Commission informed.
(2) Yes the Australian Heritage Commission has entered the Cairns Customs House in the Register of the National Estate.

The Commission has been in contact with both the National Trust of Queensland and local Cairns heritage support groups concerning the Customs House and has requested information on any development proposals known to those bodies for the building. If a firm proposal emerges for development at the Customs House the Commission will advise owners and proposed developers of the national estate values of the place and request that these be considered in any decision making process.

It should be noted that the Customs House is neither owned by the Commonwealth nor is there known direct Commonwealth involvement in any concept for redevelopment of the site. Therefore there is no involvement by the Australian Heritage Commission under Section 30 of its Act.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 14 December 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the failed Magnetic Quays marina development at Nelly Bay on Magnetic Island, North Queensland:
(1) Why was the Deed of Agreement not provided under the discovery procedures at the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) hearings in 1989 and 1990.

(2) Why did the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority (GBRMPA) claim at the AAT hearings that the breakwalls were removable, but are now claiming that they are not and never were intended to be removed (refer to Don Kinsey's affidavit to AAT, 21/8/89, and Judge Bulley's decision, 29/8/89).

(3) If removal of the breakwalls was never to be required why was a Deed of Agreement signed by the GBRMPA specifically requiring the removal of the breakwalls in the event of the developer's insolvency.
(4) If removal of the breakwalls was never to be required how did the GBRMPA propose to rehabilitate the Marine Park in the event of the financial failure of the developer prior to the completion.
(5) On what evidence does the GBRMPA base its claim that removal of the breakwalls is impracticable.
(6) On what evidence does the GBRMPA base its claim that removal of the breakwalls would cause unacceptable environmental impacts and when did the GBRMPA form this opinion.

(7) Given that the Magnetic Quays project has now been abandoned and the lease surrendered, will the GBRMPA invoke the Deed of Agreement requiring the developer to remove the structures and rehabilitate the Marine Park before it expires in April 1993.
(8) On the assumption that the developer cannot and will not rehabilitate the Marine Park, will the GBRMPA undertake to carry out the necessary work required to restore the World Heritage area.

(9) How and why were the concerns of the GBRMPA assistant executive officer (Mr Simon Woodley) raised in his letter of 4 August 1989, that the insurance policy failed to meet the requirements of the Deed of Agreement, satisfied so that on 14 August 1989, only 10 days later, the project was given the go-ahead and was the GBRMPA threatened in any way by the developer or any person or body causing its rapid change of heart.

(10) What was the basis of the legal advice from both the Australian Government Solicitor and the Attorney-General's Department that led to the decision to approve the project without adequate insurance.
(11) What legal advice was received by GBRMPA for its proposed application for a Stay Order on works in the Marine Park in August 1989 and why did GBRMPA not apply for a Stay Order at that time.

(12) Why did the GBRMPA Chairman (Mr Graeme Kelleher) feel compelled to convince the Magnetic Quays developer (Mr Peter McLean) to press ahead with the project after the Authority had decided against supporting the development as proposed (refer to phone note of 25 October 1988).

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Authority issued a permit to Magnetic Keys Ltd on 28 October 1988. The Deed of Agreement between the Authority and Magnetic Keys Ltd was finalised in March 1989.

The documentation for the first hearing of the AAT was prepared in May 1989, and included the material pertinent to the Authority's decision to issue the permit to Magnetic Keys up to early April 1989. The Deed was not included with this documentation as it did not relate to the sequence of events leading the Authority to make the original decision to issue a permit (rather, it was a consequence of that decision).

The Deed was included in the material prepared for the second hearing of the AAT appeal in March 1990 on the basis that it, and other documents, helped show the progress of events during the period between April 1989 and March 1990 hearings; the material in the second list was not tabled as Island Voice withdrew the appeal (on 5 March 1990) prior to the hearing commencing (set for 19 March 1990).

(2) The Authority does not claim that the breakwalls cannot be removed. It was and is still the Authority's view that once the walls were completed, removal would cause greater environmental impact than leaving them in place. This was stated in the notice printed in the Gazette (No. S390) dated 15 December 1988 giving the reasons for the Authority's decision to grant a permit for the development.

Dr Kinsey's affidavit of 21 August 1989 contains reference to the possibility of the removal of only the thin sheet piling used in the construction of the walls—not the completed breakwalls themselves.

On 25 August 1989 (not 29 August 1989) Judge Bulley lifted a temporary Stay of Works that he had imposed on the project on 16 August 1989. The Authority undertook to inform the AAT when work at the site would cause irreversible changes to the Marine Park and did so in February 1990.

(3) It is not true to say that removal of the breakwalls was never a requirement. The intent of the provisions in the Deed was to ensure that the capacity existed to remove partially completed walls if necessary—for instance if they were unstable and unsafe.
(4) Not applicable (see (3) above).

(5) and (6) In the notice published in the Gazette (No.S390) dated 15 December 1988 giving the reasons for the Authority's decision to grant a permit for the development, it was stated that it was the Authority's view that the removal of the breakwalls would not be considered feasible (ie. would be impracticable) once the walls were completed because it would involve risk of unacceptable environmental damage to the Marine Park.

The October 1988 assessment report on the Magnetic Quays development stated that the walls should be considered permanent facilities. Subsequent discussions between the Authority and the Australian Construction Services on whether physically removing all traces of the completed breakwalls was possible, concluded that such large-scale works would inevitably lead to significant silt production in the rest of Nelly Bay and the release of sulphides and rust into the Marine Park from the remnants of the sheet piling at the centre of the walls.
The Authority has had extensive experience with the environmental assessment of other large scale developments in the Marine Park eg. Hamilton Island runway.
(8) No. Attempting to rehabilitate or restore the Magnetic Quays site would damage the Marine Park.

(9) The Authority received expert advice on the application of the insurance policy from Sedgwick James Ltd, Australia's largest insurance brokers on the same day that the policy was queried by Mr Woodley. This advice was accepted by the Authority as indicating that the insurance would answer the matters raised in Mr Woodley's query.
The GBRMPA was not threatened by any party during this time or at any other time.
(10) I am not satisfied that there was at any stage a decision to "approve the project without adequate insurance".

(11) The GBRMPA received legal advice from the Australian Government Solicitor (AGS) on application of a Stay Order on 7 and 8 August 1989. The AGS advised that it would be a legitimate stance for the Authority not to apply for a Stay Order.

On the basis of this advice, the Authority Chairman, with the support of other Authority members, decided not to apply for a Stay Order at that time, because no works which might cause irreversible damage to the Marine Park were imminent.

(12) The GBRMPA Chairman did not convince the developer to press ahead after the Authority had decided against the proposed development. The developer had been working to meet the Authority's requirements for several years, and the remaining problems identified by the Authority at its meeting of 24 October 1988, were of a technical nature for which the Authority believed the developer would be able to find satisfactory solutions. The Authority's view was conveyed to the developer by the Chairman as part of his proper duties.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 14 December 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the television documentary entitled Shoalwater up for Grabs, shown by Channel 7 on 29 November 1992:

(1) Has the Minister noted that various employees of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) were depicted in the documentary, or their views were referred to, in all cases, as being critical of sand-mining proposals in the area.
(2) Were those employees shown in the documentary: (a) speaking on behalf of the CSIRO or as private individuals; and (b) appearing in the documentary during their normal hours of duty or on leave.
(3) Who in the CSIRO authorised the CSIRO technician to speak in the documentary on behalf of the organisation.

(4) Does the Minister and senior CSIRO management endorse all the views attributed to the CSIRO in the course of the documentary; if not, what views do the Minister and/or CSIRO senior management not endorse, and why.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) One only CSIRO staff member, a technician, appeared on the program. His statements did not indicate he was against the mining proposal. The statements made related to the likely consequences of such mining.

(2)(a) The comments were based on official CSIRO reviews of the Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) prepared for the sand mining proposal within the Shoalwater Bay Training Area. These reviews became public domain when sent by the Army to the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories as part of their formal response to the EIS.

(b) He was appearing during normal hours of duty. The two reasons for his appearance on the program were that he has extensive knowledge of the environment of the Shoalwater Bay Training Area as a result of 17 years involvement in studies concerned with the management of the Training Area; and because the Training Area is a restricted place, it was necessary to have the film party accompanied by someone who was aware of the procedures to be followed and the obligations to safety.
(3) The technician was authorised by his superior, Dr Brian Tunstall, to assist the production by way of providing technical detail and facilitating access.

(4) The views expressed by the CSIRO officer in the program reflect CSIRO's general responsibility to provide authoritative and independent advice to Government, industry and community groups. In this instance, CSIRO prepared detailed comments on the EIS on sandmining in Shoalwater Bay Training Area at the request of the Army and publicly declared its findings.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 14 December 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the television documentary entitled Shoalwater up for Grabs, shown by Channel 7 on 29 November 1992:

(1) What `government report' was it that is alleged in the documentary to have found that there was only a 2 per cent chance of any company making a profit from sand-mining in the Shoalwater Bay area.
(2) Please provide a copy of the relevant report.
(3) Does the Government accept that the findings of the report are as reported in the documentary.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1, & 3) I know of no `government report' that states there is only a 2 percent chance of any company making a profit from sand mining in the Shoalwater Bay area. However, in mid 1990 the Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics (BMR) was requested to prepare a financial evaluation report on the leases now held by Pivot Mining Pty Ltd, which cover only a small portion of the Shoalwater Bay area. This evaluation concluded that there is a `98 per cent probability that the project would show a zero or less rate of return'. The analysis was based only on data set out in the Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) submitted by Pivot and estimates made by the BMR. Its conclusions take no account of the potential for discovery of further heavy mineral deposits, either within the area of the leases or elsewhere in the Shoalwater Bay area.
(2) A copy of the BMR evaluation is available from the Senate Table Office.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 15 December 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the television documentary entitled Shoalwater Bay up for Grabs, shown by Channel 7 on 29 November 1992:
(1) (a) What was the stated purpose on the application for access by the documentary crew; (b) who approved the application; and (c) what conditions were stipulated in relation to the visit.
(2) Did the Army or the Department of Defence make available transport or other assistance to the film team; if so, at what cost and was reimbursement sought and obtained.

(3) How many military exercises have taken place within the Shoalwater Bay Training Area (SWBTA) over the past 2 years, and how have they been conducted so as to ensure that the area is `pristine', as distinct from making minimum impact on the environment of the area.
(4) Does the Minister endorse or accept the view attributed to the Officer in Charge of SWBTA that his function is to look after this `pristine piece of countryside'.

(5) What are the exciting discoveries made by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) in the course of its function, described by the Army spokesman in the documentary as `chief adviser' to the Army.
(6) How has the Army been able to carry out military exercises and other activities for 25 years while the SWBTA remains a `wilderness'.
(7) What are the estimated populations of: (a) feral animals; (b) cattle; and (c) brumbies or wild horses, within the SWBTA.
(8) Was the view of the headland shown in the documentary and described as pristine wilderness in fact the view of part of a gunnery range.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) The stated purpose of the application by the film crew was to highlight the impact of planned or proposed sand mining in the Shoalwater Bay Training Area (SWBTA) and Byfield areas.
(b) The application was approved by Major Hassall, former Officer Commanding District Support Unit Rockhampton, through Headquarters First Military District Operations.
(c) Conditions of entry were:
(i) The crew were given access only under escort; and
(ii) SWBTA Standing Orders were strictly adhered to.

(2) No transport was made available to the film crew but the military escort was provided with a service/departmental vehicle. It is part of normal operational procedure to provide a military escort, for civilians on SWBTA, and no reimbursement of costs was sought.

(3) Training that has taken place over the last two years include: 34 regiment/battalion size exercises, 64 company strength or less exercises and approximately 100 visits by small parties for reconnaissance purposes.

With regard to environmental management the following occurs each time any military users have access to the SWBTA. Standing Orders on issue to all user units are read and the information contained therein is disseminated to all rank levels. Unit representatives are briefed in detail, prior to entry, by the Range Control Officer (RCO). The three `on site' permanent caretakers continually patrol all areas to ensure strict compliance with all orders as above mentioned and the environmental policy as detailed in the brief. A detailed inspection of all areas used by the units is conducted by the RCO before units are cleared. Repairs are carried out if necessary.

(4) Yes. Environmental management is a major function of the Officer Commanding (OC) the SWBTA. All incoming OCs are briefed on their environmental management responsibilities and are provided with briefing and land management information to assist in this function during their tenure with the unit.
It is a basic principle of Defence land management that the property is used and managed in such a way as to maintain it at, or as close as possible to, its natural condition.
(5) SWBTA is in an area where the Subtropical Zone merges with the Tropical Zone and the Desert Zone. This creates a rich mixture of flora and fauna communities.

For example the fauna survey, undertaken by CSIRO, revealed the presence of a distinctive specimen of the Yellow-bellied Sheathtail Bat in the SWBTA. It may prove to represent a new species. If this is so, it is rare and possibly locally endemic.
(6) Impact Zones for exercises are selected so that no fragile habitat is used. Mt Hummock is the present impact zone for artillery bombardment. This area does not contain any fragile environments.
Exercises are limited to periods of the year when the habitat is least vulnerable, such as, between January to August when the fire risk and fauna breeding activity is low.
Ground exercises are kept hygienically clean and crews repair all clearings and excavations as required.

(7) (a) Feral animals: The Shoalwater Bay Training Area Fauna Survey prepared by CSIRO and published in December 1992, indicates that there are nine species of feral animals in SWBTA; Cane Toad, House Mouse, European Rabbit, Red Fox, Cat, Horse, Pig, Cattle and Feral Goats. The number of Cane Toads has not been established. House Mice are limited to disturbed ground around man-made structures. The European Rabbit, Cat and the Red Fox are uncommon within the SWBTA. Pigs are widespread despite a regular culling program. Townshend Island contains an estimated population of 3,000 feral goats. The study did not investigate full populations of feral animals.
(b) Cattle: Cattle are abundant and widespread in herds of up to 50 animals. The cattle are remnants of previous use of the SWBTA. No precise population numbers are available for cattle within SWBTA.
(c) Brumbies or wild horses: Horses are abundant and widespread with herds numbering up to 30 animals. No precise population details are available for horses within SWBTA.
(8) The view shown in the documentary a view of the headland, was not part of the Gunnery Range but the Freshwater Sector Headland.
